messages: 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:59): Man, the -S option to git log is slow.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:59): Totally CPU-bound.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:59): (Of course, SVN doesn't even offer it.  I shudder to think what it would be like trying to do that client-side with SVN.)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:00): realizes that for his purposes he can just use git bisect
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:00): hates how you need one good rev and one bad for that to work, though . . .
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:04): Hmm, git isn't so happy with multi-MB files either, probably.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:09): Wow, most complex chord I've ever had to type.  Ctrl+Shift+Alt+S
a0f2d35bbc48e637c7fcaaa946ceaa60 (01:11): export for web devices?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:11): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: not an emacs user i assume
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:12): a0f2d35bbc48e637c7fcaaa946ceaa60: Well, sorta.  Generate db schema in HTML.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: No, and that's why.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Also, elisp.  Yuck.  Worst extant dialect of Lisp ever.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:12): hehe
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:13): a0f2d35bbc48e637c7fcaaa946ceaa60: What program does that option match with this chord?
a0f2d35bbc48e637c7fcaaa946ceaa60 (01:13): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: Photoshop
a0f2d35bbc48e637c7fcaaa946ceaa60 (01:13): i think, at least :)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:13): I'm a GIMP user, so I wouldn't know.
a0f2d35bbc48e637c7fcaaa946ceaa60 (01:14): i run cs4 through a xp vm :p
a0f2d35bbc48e637c7fcaaa946ceaa60 (01:14): gonna start using gimp when get around to grab the latest which has all windows encapsulated
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:15): woo, dinnertime!
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:15): omnomnoms.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:20): Has there ever been rel="edit" in the spec?
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (01:30): just registered for Google I/O
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (01:30): anyone else going?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:33): Why would you want to embed media via QuickTime if you have video and audio?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:34): Maybe you want to use those totally useful "3D" QuickTime things where you can rotate the view
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:40): You mean like you can do with <canvas>?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:40): looks questioningly at 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:43): Why would you want to embed media via QuickTime if you have video and audio?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:43): (in reference to a mailing list post of your from a few hours ago)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:44): 1) if you want to target browsers that don't have <video> yet
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:44): 2) if you want to target browsers that don't support your codec of choice in <video>

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:44): 3) if you want to embed content types that are supported by the QuickTime plugin but not any browser's <video> or <audio> because they are not strictly speaking either video or audio, such as QuickTime VR content or Quartz Composer content

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:44): Yes, but in the context of the thread we're talking about <iframe sandbox>.  I'm pretty sure all browsers that support that would support <video> . . . and with any luck they'll also have settled on a common codec.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:45): Okay, I guess.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:45): just tryin' to answer your question
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:45): I am not saying I <3 the QuickTime plugin
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:45): 4) Maybe you hate your users and want to make their browsers slow and crashy
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:45): Nah, it would be easier to use Flash then.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:47): As one participant in this conversation can attest, judging by his recent fascinating post to public-html today.  :)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:48): somehow managed to get Flash consistently crashing Linux Chrome, when Chrome is supposed to be immune to plugin crashes.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:48): Maybe it's a feature
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:49): disables plugins in his main browser, and has a different browser that he uses almost solely for Flash sites
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:49): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, me too, but only because plugins don't seem to work with my Linux Chrome yet.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:49): If YouTube used <video>, I'd be set.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:53): I wonder what the status on <video>-in-YouTube is.  Sadly, I imagine it's "shelve it until <video> is actually better".
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:53): imagines a service that takes a non-<video> video as input and gives a <video> <source> as output
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:54): Probably expensive bandwidth-wise, but you could throw in ads and stuff maybe :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:54): still not jgraham?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:54): gsnedders?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:54): s/not/no/
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:06): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: to be fair, Flash was hanging, not crashing
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:09): Oh, well, that's okay, then.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:21): (totally off-topic)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:29): That kind of journalistic integrity is rare nowadays
